The range of the EBITDA objectives to improve profitability is still the long-term target. And as you saw so far, we kept a good margin in the U.S. despite the economic crisis and the toughened environment.

Just maybe to add on the long-term margin target René just mentioned, remember, we always had a long-term margin target in the U.S. of 35%. That obviously includes cost programs. We're not guiding a single cost element, but the long-term margin of 35% in the U.S. is completely intact.
On the VDSL environment, I understand now the question is have we commercial contracts to open the network.

Yeah, the regulatory environments. To me, it's important that regulation takes into account that we have a new competitive environment with cable, with wireless and with DSL networks. And therefore, on the new networks, fiber optic or VDSL networks, one changes from ex ante to ex post regulation and reduces our obligation, which is still in place. And that is so far not the case.

However, we see there is a bit of rethinking going on, because everybody understands that those highly CapEx or high CapEx intense networks can only be built if you have an incentive for investors to make those necessary investments. And therefore, one would imagine to be able to allow risk-sharing, for instance, long-term contracts with resellers and also network sharing. So those things are currently under consideration.
I expect, I hope at least, that the regulator improves the environment so we can make those investments.

I think we continue with the next email question, Paul Marsh from . Paul, you are also on our phone list, so please let us know whether that we tackle now all of your questions. It's three of them basically. And we start with the first one. The first one is, can you update us on the ARPU uplift from smartphone customers. And the second question is how much of the margin uplift in systems and solution was related to lower levels of business activity in CDS. For example, you do having few engineers, consultants out in the field et cetera. Is the margin improvement sustainable once business levels recover?

Maybe I start with the second one and then hand over to Tim and René. Remember that we always said, with respect to the two systems margin, we will be getting towards a level of mid single-digit. So far key systems is not so much a story of growth, especially in the late cyclical environment we are in. It is a question of EBIT margin improvement. You saw the contribution of 100 million in the third quarter alone to our Safe for Service initiative. So what we do in T systems is bringing down the cost base significantly and sustainably towards the mid single-digit margin target we have. And I don't think that the margin uplift or the sustainability of the margin is anyhow dependent of the recovery of the business. Remember, in the third quarter, is the first quarter where we saw actually late cyclical impact and the margin improvement was 2.9 to 3%. The big margin uplift we saw were the 12 months before was not at all related to a weakness in the underlying business.

I think the question on smartphone customers briefly answered. We saw the most precise impact from the iPhone as I said earlier on with about €1 impact on the overall base, 1.2 million iPhones sold so far. So the ARPU of iPhone customers are in the vicinity of €74 in Germany which is significantly higher than the average.

In general premium devices and smartphones go along with bigger minute bundles and data flat rates. So they generally represent high spending customers and early adopters or inoperative high usage customers. And therefore it's important for us to keep distributing and marketing those premium products to get premium customers.

I would like to answer the question with regards to the development in the wireline business and especially in the area of the broadband development. I think as a first statement in the wireline area, the broadband growth on double play and as well on triple play that is as we call it the holy land, that is the area we want to grow. This is the area where we see the ARPU stabilization, this is the area we will see the loyalty, this is the area where we see the customer satisfaction increasing. This is the innovation part and therefore we are not only in Germany focusing on these areas, but as well in our SEE countries. And I wanted to give you an indication that we are not only successful in Germany where we hold now a constant market share of 46% and increasing market share on the triple play area. We had an increase in market telecom of 10% year-over-year on the broadband growth. We had 22% in Telecom, 18% in Slovak Telekom, 32% in Romtelecom and 30% growth on all degrees.

So in all of these countries, we are significantly growing on the double plays and the triple plays offering and therefore we are doing a lot to bring the Entertain product, the content products into these areas. And it's definitely the area we are focusing on, and we see good developments in almost every market and therefore, yes – definitely, yes, this is the area where we want to compensate and where we see the compensation for the decline in the single-play area.
Thank you very much, Tim. I think we will we having a further question out of the room. Peter-Kurt?

Thank you. Just returning to the earlier subject of U.S. contract ARPUs. How do you foresee or expect the impact of your new tarrif auctions which are obviously quite material on the contract ARPU side? Thank you.

Yes, the expectation certainly is to attract new high spending customers as well as high usage customers, as well as you now have something to offer for existing customer base. So we do that in order to regain some momentum and to reposition the brand as a good value alternative to AT&T and Verizon. That's where we want the brand to be and so certainly we have an expectation there. But it's again it's too early to make any specific forecasts and I would be somewhat cautious there.

Peter-Kurt, remember that only two weeks now out in the field with a new tariff plan. We continue with the next question handed in by phone and I would like to welcome Mr. Simon Weeden from Merrill Lynch. Simon?
Thank you very much, Stefan. But my questions have been answered and have certainly have been asked several times, anyway. Thank you.
Thank you so much. And then we continue with Mr. Chris Nickelson from Oraca. Chris, are you online?
Yes, hello good morning. Can you hear me? Can you hear me?
Yes, perfectly fine.

Great. Okay. I wondered if you could give us some steer on the interest that the German government pays to Deutsche Telekom's cost cutting exercises within the home market? And it might be simpler to scale it, perhaps zero being absolutely no interest at all, five being acutely interested in what you're planning?

The government has 32% directly and indirectly in DT and they have one representative from the Finance Ministry on the Supervisory Board as well as the Head of KfW on our Board. So they have two board members our of 20 and of course they will – they're watching the large companies and their activities as they have to watch the economical development and they're interested in the big companies to flourish. But other than that, their influence is being taken through the Supervisory Board and they are – they have two votes out of 20.
Thank you.

And sorry, if I may add one more sentence. Since a couple of years, you see us quite rigorous on our cost management side and efficiency management side and we've taken also the necessary steps in order to be more competitive in Germany. That was certainly not very popular but the previous governments did not interfere, they let us do what we needed to do from an entrepreneurial perspective. And as a result now, Deutsche Telekom is much more competitive in Germany and performs better and I think that solution is for everyone at the end of the day.
Thank you, René. I really liked the question. We continue with Mr. Brian Rusling from Cazenove. Brian?

Yeah. The question is about Germany and fixed line specifically, can you just talk to how the changes in Q3 have come through with the minus 3.5% revenues in the fixed network in Q3, versus the sort of minus five to 6% we had in Q1 and Q2. Why has there have been an improvement? What specific elements have led to that fall getting smaller and also on the entertainment packages that you are selling, can you give us a sense of -- out of the three packages out there, are they all at the lower end or are they at the top end of the ARPU?

Brian, if I may I start with the first question. You're correct, it was minus 5.3 and the second quarter is minus 3.5 actually in the third quarter. The main drivers are a) lower line losses year-over-year, nine months over nine months. And the second driver is obviously a price stabilization. Remember that the last big price round, we saw in double play in Germany was over two years ago, that was in August 2007. And that price stabilization especially on the double-play front is now thus starting to feed through. When it comes to Entertain packages, I think of the best sold package we have is actually the mid package. And when it comes to the ARPU it is in the mid 40s, it's €143. Does that answer your question, Brian?

It does. I'm interested also, whether there is a sort of a kicker that comes in when you sign up these entertainment people in terms of any hardware like a box sale or whatever that may kick in to your third quarter results with the assumption of benefit?

You know, the good thing is we have changed our policy with regards to the subscriber acquisition costs and with the subsidy of you know the box i.e., any kind of hardware. And today you know, and by the way it's almost 80% of all these customers. They are not any longer own their box. They rent it from us. So it's not one period subsidizing any more, it's now stretched over the entire duration of the contract and the customer is paying for that within the ARPU model. So I think that is helping us as well here on that one. We could always make some kind of advertisements around that. For instance, we could say for the first six months or 12 months there is no rent on the box. So you do not have to pay that. We use that as a promotional offer in the market, especially in the Christmas business these days. So this is, let's say, a kind of more regional, let's say, a selective instrument than rather let's say a kind of price reduction on our overall product.
Thank you Tim. I think we'll be continuing with the last email contribution we've got. It is from Robin Binstock of Bernstein. Robin, good morning and I think I'll hand over to Rene.

Yeah. The question is on our expectation with regards to cable companies, whether they present an increasing threat or a decreasing threat to our broadband share? And I said it earlier on we take the cable competition very serious and we believe that the overall service experience from sales to installation, to device, to bandwidth and to the content service has to be competitive, not just the pure exit site, although that plays a roll. So we take it serious.

We target the areas also with specific attention where we would expect the strongest competition. So they are showing growing net add share but I believe so far more at the cost of our competitors, of our DSL competitors. And so far only Vodafone, the cable companies and ourselves, we are growing. And as far as guidance for next year goes, I'm afraid I can't give it yet. But, be assured we have that on our radar screen and we target specifically the key competitors of today and tomorrow. We do the right things for our customers.

Do we expect a tougher broadband? That's the next question. Broadband pricing environment, we are as now seem likely that's your question, Robin. And the answer is, actually last year stable pricing in Germany across the market that was the case. And as far as we go we would focus even more on the higher value propositions on triple play and try and sell the premium packages and we keep focus on quality and service, onsite service, installation service, really trying to be a no worry service provider for our customers, that's what we invest in. So it is quite difficult to say what would happen if that takeover has really taken place. I think that's a bit too difficult to forecast.

Thank you René. I think we've got two more questions by the phone and the second try of Ulrich . Also Matthew from Deutsche Bank and Paul Marsh. I and my colleague will contact directly if there is open questions and I think the second last question comes from Larry Sugarman from ING. Larry?
Can you hear me now?
Yes. Now I can hear you.

Fantastic. I just wanted to ask on the Netherlands. Obviously, very big improvement in the margin in the quarter, I wanted to get your thoughts on -- first of all is that -- are there any other issues that explain that beyond the normal operating trading? And also should we be considering that as a good indication of the potential around in-market mobile consolidation.

I think we are, as well, quite pleased with the development in the Netherlands and the trends which we are seeing. You know that we have this business case with regard to our inter-market consolidation with Orange and we now see the benefits out of that deal coming in. We have only one cluster cost – fixed cost development. We have the IT and the network now together and we have as well a good – additional top line and EBITDA development which is coming from this MD&O which we have with till two. So overall, this thing has developed quite reasonable and do you – if you would ask me, now could you increase beyond what you had in mind to the business case, you know, let me be cautious on that one. Now we will deliver first on the integration plan. We are absolutely in line with the revenues and as well with the cost synergies which we had in our business case and in 2010 then having continuous profitability in that business then we might talk about further developments here.

Larry, it is clear that this is a real good example for the potential mobile market in consolidation. I think we've been waiting for it for a while so far, but we're pleased with the outcome in the Netherlands and in particular in the third quarter. Now, then we come to the last caller, it's Jonathan Dan from Barclays. Jonathan, are you online?

Yes, I just have one question, I'll spread it into two parts. If you look at the markets that you have consolidated, the Netherlands, UK, Austria, what triggered the final decision to consolidate and how does that compare to the U.S. market today?

The tail effects, we have said almost three years ago that we would focus on intra-country consolidation and then potentially on adjacent markets. But most important is the scale effect, the CapEx in any one country is pretty high and if you don't have certain levels of market share in a market which then is mature which doesn't grow then you're not so well off. So therefore the scale and the synergies intra-country are the most easy to reap and that's why the focus was on lease to internal consolidations first.

While the U.S. market is a little different in terms of characteristics, first of all in Europe there are dozens and dozens of different players competing for the same cake. And in the U.S. there are only four national players. And the U.S. market is pretty big with 300 million customers and mobile data and mobile Internet revenue in the U.S. grows very strong. As the U.S. has traditionally been very and early adopting. And so will the mobile Internet play a significant role in the business in the U.S. market. And therefore it's kind of hard to compare markets like Austria or the Netherlands where there are four or five players used to be in Austria, five, Netherlands as well. You can't compare that with the U.S. market, it's a different size, different characteristics. And therefore a conclusion like you're suggesting is not an automatic conclusion.

Rene, thank you very, very much. I think we are finished with the Q&A session. I think we will see most of you or many of you in our road show will be starting tomorrow with René and Tim in Frankfurt. Then Tim will be for two days in London next week, René and myself will be in the U.S. We will very much looking forward to meet all of you and discuss especially after these strong third quarter results, the outcome of the quarter, plus also what we're seeing as developments going forward with all of you. Thank you very much and good bye.
